results.title: Council discusses climate plan, energy plant at April meeting
results.content: 18 hours ago — The Campus Sustainability Executive Council convened Tuesday, April 9, to discuss the following topics: Climate Action Plan next steps.
results.markdown_content:
The Campus Sustainability Executive Council convened Tuesday, April 9, to discuss the following topics:

## Climate Action Plan next steps
**Discussion: **The council discussed the state of the Climate Action Plan (CAP) and the intention to release a final version during the campus leadership panel at the Campus Sustainability Summit. Vice Chancellor for Infrastructure and Sustainability Chris Ewing presented the [10 main feedback themes (PDF)](https://www.colorado.edu/sustainability/sites/default/files/attached-files/cap_feedback_incorporation.pdf) that the CAP steering committee extracted from the more than 600 comments that were received during the open comment period.
**Decision:** The [updated CAP was announced](https://www.colorado.edu/today/2024/04/25/final-climate-action-plan-released) during the Campus Sustainability Summit. This is a living document that will be revised, added to and improved upon over time.
## West District Energy Plant update
**Discussion:** A faculty, staff and student shared governance group that includes members from the Boulder Faculty Assembly, faculty from the College of Engineering and Applied Science and the law school, and a graduate student from the law school submitted a report recommending alternatives to the [planned West District Energy Plant upgrades](https://www.colorado.edu/today/2023/11/08/correction-regent-approved-energy-plant-upgrades-reduce-nitrogen-oxides-help-meet-new-air) following a deeper review of the project.
**Next steps: **The alternative plan is being assessed to determine next steps related to the project.
*This is part of a series that will cover CU Boulder Sustainability Executive Council meeting agendas, discussions and decisions. The Sustainability Executive Council brings together decision-makers and leaders from across campus to drive action and accountability to achieve carbon neutrality, goals outlined in the chancellor’s Call to Climate Action and the implementation of the campus Climate Action Plan. *

results.title: North Central Climate Adaptation Science Center: welcome
results.content: 13 hours ago — The North Central Climate Adaptation Science Center is a partnership between the US Geological Survey, the University of Colorado Boulder and five consortium ...
results.markdown_content:
**The North Central Climate Adaptation Science Center is a partnership between the US Geological Survey, the University of Colorado Boulder and five consortium partners. The NC CASC fosters innovative and applied research in support of tribal, federal, state, and local natural resource management and decision-making. The North Central center is one of nine regional climate centers in the national CASC network created to help meet the changing needs of land and resource managers across the country. It serves Colorado, Wyoming, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Kansas and Nebraska. **
# welcome
#### Traditional Ecological Knowledge
There is an increasing demand to integrate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) with Western science for climate change adaptation. However, the challenge lies in how climate, ecological, and social scientists can collaborate equitably with Tribal communities to achieve this.

results.title: Colorado River might recover from two-decade drought ...
results.content: 15 hours ago — A new study coming from researchers at CU Boulder, reveals that precipitation, not temperature, will keep the Colorado River fuller than previous research ...
results.markdown_content:
# Colorado River might recover from two-decade drought thanks to precipitation
The American Southwest and its drinking water may not be in as bad of shape as originally thought. A new study coming from researchers at CU Boulder, reveals that *precipitation*, not temperature, will keep the Colorado River fuller than previous research told us.

The Journal of Climate published the study Tuesday as a guide for policymakers, water managers, states and tribes to figure out how to monitor the river until 2050. New guidelines are going to replace regulations from 2007, which are set to expire at the end of 2026.

Comprehensive climate model analysis from CIRES, an institute of the University of Colorado Boulder, forecasting precipitation for the next 25 years, shows a 70% chance of increased precipitation compared with the last two decades, which brought the Colorado River to a devastating drought.

"The temperature is warming, but that's not the full story -- you add precipitation and you get a fuller picture," says Balaji Rajagopalan, co-author of the study.

Researchers studied Lee's Ferry flows, which are the dividing point of the Colorado's upper and lower basins, and where many tourists typically launch boats into the Grand Canyon.

"We find it is more likely than not that Lee Ferry flows will be greater during 2026-2050 than since 2000 as a consequence of a more favorable precipitation cycle," says Martin Hoerling, the paper's lead author. "This will compensate the negative effects of more warming in the near term. There's roughly a 4% chance that Lee Ferry flows could decline another 20% in the next quarter century compared to the last 20 years."

Colorado River headwaters originate as snow in Colorado and Wyoming mountains above 10,000 feet and supplies water to 40 million people in seven states and parts of Mexico.

Scientists have regarded 15 million acre feet of water as a key figure in measuring Colorado River flows. They've garnered that the river has had extreme wet and dry periods throughout the last century starting in 1895. Since the 2000 megadrought, the river has produced around 12.5 million acre feet each year. Arizona, California and Nevada have agreed to save three million acre feet ahead of the 2026 deadline.

results.title: Four Corners Climate Summit: Building community to grow ...
results.content: 11 hours ago — More than 400 people attended the inaugural Summit, aimed at fostering awareness and unity around regional climate interests and building resilience to climate ...
results.markdown_content:
307


## Four Corners Climate Summit: Building community to grow climate adaptation in the Western Slope
### More than 400 people attended the inaugural Summit, aimed at fostering awareness and unity around regional climate interests and building resilience to climate change.
DURANGO, Colo.— Sitting in a circle outside the President’s Office at Fort Lewis College, renowned environmental writer Terry Tempest-Williams and a handful of students discussed writing, art, activism, and the intersectionality of all three.

“I can tell you I was changed,” Tempest-Williams would later tell more than 400 people during her keynote speech at the inaugural Four Corners Climate Summit.

The intimate meeting preceded the day-long summit, which included presentations by the authors of the Fifth National Climate Assessment, artists, and local environment and sustainability advocates.

“The fact that traditional knowledge is being integrated and used with Western science [at FLC], the fact that there’s now greater representation of Native people in all aspects of leadership... it was something so much deeper than hope,” she said. “If we focus on the changes and the possibilities we see, then I believe we are on the right path.”

**Tracking challenges to build resilience**

Attendees gathered at the Student Union Ballroom for the main event, packed with expert panels, presentations by local organizations, and art expressing the impact of climate changes.

In the morning, presentations were led by scientists and authors of the [Fifth National Climate Assessment](https://nca2023.globalchange.gov/), discussing the impacts of climate change on human health, wildfires, agriculture, and drought.

Art also played a significant role in the Summit, with the Art x Climate Gallery showcasing the impact of climate change through artistic expression.

In addition, outside the Ballroom, attendees were greeted by a large art piece depicting a river. The project came from Keri Brandt Off's Animacy and Kinship class. Off is a sociology professor at FLC.

“We collectively decided that we wanted to create an artistic display of the animacy of all elements of life, including rivers, mountains, animals, soil, and water, and that we wanted to do it in the spirit of kinship and solidarity.”

Students found materials and brought their sewing machines, glue, and scissors to work on the project.

“For two weeks, we sat on the floor and tried to create this project that represented how we felt about the animacy of water, the life of water, and the value of water to all beings. It was partly inspired by the Rights of Rivers gathering in October in the fall. And so, it was in honor of the Rights of Rivers. It was just this exciting collective project where we decided to decenter traditional academic practice to think about new ideas and ways of relating together to create knowledge and beauty.”

**Four Corners in action**

Following a lunch provided with support from the USDA Southwest Climate Hub, Tempest-Williams talked about her meeting with the six FLC students and how impressed she had been with them and shared stories of community resilience, citing examples such as efforts to address the declining levels of the Great Salt Lake.

“Today, the story of colonialism is being transformed into a story of restoration and integration, where crisis is becoming a consensus to change,” she said. “Together, our collective works can change the weather system... the political weather, the spiritual weather, and become pragmatic visionaries like I saw today with the students here at Fort Lewis.”

The FLC students who had met with her in the morning were delighted.

“This experience with Terry… it was absolutely incredible,” said senior Brooke Laughter, a [Tribal Water Media Fellow](https://www.fourcornerswater.org/tribal-water-media) who talked about how through her film “[They Call Me Water](https://www.fourcornerswater.org/portals/18/assets/media/2023-twmf/brooke_laughter_they-call-me-water.mov),” she wanted to highlight the Indigenous perspective of considering water as a living being. Laughter graduated Saturday with a B.S. in Environmental Science.


“It really invigorated me and my understanding that there are many forms of activism and that every little piece helps. That's very exciting. It's changed my view of my form of activism, my art.”

“It was really magical,” added Tanner Besse, who graduated Cum Laude on Saturday with a B.A. in Environmental Conservation Management, a minor in Sociology and Human Services, and a Regenerative Food Certificate. “She put a lot of things that I was thinking into words. Her courageous conversation resonated with me; if we trust ourselves with the future, that's a powerful tool. Seeing someone so wise as Terry taking time with a bunch of 20-year-olds and showing how hopeful she is in us just fuels that part of me that wants to cause change and create change that helps more people.’


The final portion of the public event was held at the Center of Southwest Studies’ exhibit “Coloradans and our Shared Environment in Times of Challenge and Change,” which featured talks by exhibit artists Holly Barnard, PhD (CU Boulder), and Jocelyn Catterson (Colorado Art Science Environment fellow).

Sarah Johnson, of Basalt, Colorado, works in climate change education in the Rocky Mountain region. She said the event was an excellent opportunity to hear about the latest scientific work on climate change and teach us more about the work being done in the Four Corners region.


“The State of Colorado is bigger than the I-25 corridor or the Front Range. There are so many examples of excellent relationships with the land and so many examples of people making a difference,” she said. "The different presenters affirmed the importance of storytelling. If this were a science issue, it would have been solved years ago, but it is a people issue. Hearing that in a practical, applied way was very affirming.”


Provost Mario Martinez said the call for action is also evident for the community and FLC.

“The purpose of today is to build awareness, to help you see the things that we do, but also the things that we can do together in partnership,” he said, “We've heard from powerful voices today. Voices of data, pictures, and graphics. Questions from those in attendance. Voices of poetry and writing from Terry~~i~~. Voices of song, voices of experience. Voices of our professors, staff, community members, and students. This is deep, deep work and things that we care about.”

The Summit is a collaboration between the FLC Provost Office, the FLC Foundation, the USDA Southwest Climate Hub, Department of Energy-Office of Legacy Management, and various donors.

[Visit the Four Corners Climate Summit's page to learn more.](https://www.fortlewis.edu/climate-summit)

[Donate to the Green Fund.](https://host.nxt.blackbaud.com/donor-form/?svcid=tcs&formId=22ae67e8-cfbe-441c-98b9-cd9b44e2086a&envid=p-321oQ5LY9kWPz41omOC2kg&zone=usa&utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_content=Donate%20to%20the%20Green%20Fund&utm_campaign=Thank%20you%20to%20FCCS%20Attendees)

results.title: The health and climate bills you need to know about
results.content: 13 hours ago — The health and climate bills you need to know about. All the bills, amendments and debates that shaped the legislature's work on health and the environment.
results.markdown_content:
Hey there, Colorado, and welcome to another edition of The Temperature, where this week we are in legislative overdrive.

They say all good things must come to an end, but the same is also true for bad things. Oh, no, I don’t mean the legislative session here. I was talking about your Colorado Rockies’ truly remarkable feat of ignominy: In its first 31 games of the season, the Rockies trailed at some point in each game. Never been done before in Major League Baseball.

That streak [ended last week](https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/rockies-end-historic-streak-colorado-gets-first-wire-to-wire-win-after-trailing-in-each-of-its-first-31-games/), and the Rockies celebrated by losing their next three games, including two shutouts, and yet are still, somehow, not the worst team in baseball. No matter how bad you think it is, it could always get worse.

And that brings us back to the state legislature, which today is closing out its 2024 legislative session — 705 bills in 120 days and who knows how many hours of sleep lost. But at least there’s no talk of a special session!

There was a ton that happened during those 120 days, and we have the highlights on health, climate and environmental issues below. But for even more legislative recapping, be sure to watch tomorrow for The Sun’s annual list of 101 bills to know about, assembled by our masterful — and very tired — politics team.

And with that, they say things can’t end unless they begin (they don’t really, but we’re saying it now), so let’s get to the news.

### TEMP CHECK
#### HEALTH
## No major new programs, but lots of tinkering to the health care system
**74**
The number of bills categorized as related to health care that the state legislature considered this year

Unlike in recent years during the Polis administration, this legislative session saw no big health policy overhauls. No quasi-public option insurance programs. No plans to import prescription drugs from other countries.

But what the session lacked in magnitude for health bills, it made up for in quantity. Lawmakers debated 74 bills related to health care, according to the legislature’s website, making health the second-hottest subject for bills behind the catch-all “state government” heading. There were also 34 bills related to public health, according to the website, though some bills got counted in both categories.

Here’s what happened with three bills we kept an especially close eye on. All of these have cleared both chambers and are on their way to the governor’s desk.

[ HOUSE BILL 1380:](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/hb24-1380) This bill would require owners of debt to put their names on lawsuits filed against people who owe them money. The bill follows
[reporting by The Colorado Sun and 9News](https://coloradosun.com/2024/02/19/uchealth-debt-collectors/)that showed
**UCHealth**sues thousands of patients per year but doesn’t put its name on the suits, instead allowing its debt collectors to be the named plaintiff, effectively concealing the health system’s involvement from the public. As The Sun and 9News have since learned, the practice is common — both among hospitals in Colorado and other entities suing people for debts.
A [tweak in its first committee hearing](https://coloradosun.com/2024/04/12/uchealth-medical-debt-lawsuits-bill/), to allow debt collectors to also be listed as plaintiffs, cleared the bill’s path for passage. Along the way, though, it lost a provision that would have prohibited plaintiffs from asking a judge to issue a warrant for debtors who are nonresponsive to legal proceedings.

[ SENATE BILL 203:](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/sb24-203) This bill emerged from the death of another bill,
[Senate Bill 60](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/sb24-060), that would have exempted so-called orphan drugs — drugs used to treat rare diseases — from review by the state’s price-capping
**Prescription Drug Affordability Board**. The concern with Senate Bill 60 was that pharmaceutical companies have increasingly sought orphan designations for niche uses of drugs that primarily treat more common diseases — meaning that roughly two-thirds of the drugs eligible for a PDAB review have at least one orphan designation.
Patients with rare diseases and their families [are incredibly worried](https://coloradosun.com/2024/04/30/colorado-prescription-drug-affordability-board-concerns/) that the PDAB could unintentionally make their drugs unavailable in Colorado. While many of these patients wanted to see Senate Bill 60 move forward with amendments, that didn’t happen. Instead, lawmakers passed Senate Bill 203, which requires the PDAB to consult with the state’s **Rare Disease Advisory Council** when reviewing a drug.

[ HOUSE BILL 1136:](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/hb24-1136) Coloradans broadly agree
[that too much social media use is bad for kids](https://coloradosun.com/2024/02/08/social-media-youth-mental-health/). So this bill tries to do something about that.
The bill requires social media companies to display pop-ups to users under the age of 18 either when they are on social media between the hours of 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. or when they have spent a total of one hour on the social media platform during a 24-hour period. The pop-ups will have information about how social media use impacts the physical and mental health of youth.

The bill didn’t see many big changes during its trip through the legislature, but the text is a masterwork of small lobbyist edits. The pop-ups were originally described as “warnings.” That became “notifications.” The list of what doesn’t constitute a social media platform regulated by the bill stretches across three pages and includes email services, online shopping sites, streaming platforms, teleconferencing services, gaming sites and others.

The bill also instructs the state to create an online resource bank of research about the health impacts of social media.

**10 MORE HEALTH BILLS THAT PASSED:**
**AND 5 THAT DIDN’T:**
#### MORE HEALTH NEWS
#### CLIMATE
## Big compromises on the environment, some big losses, and some lil’ chestnuts return
We here at the **Environment Home Office** are a bit fatigued by late night Avalanche overtime and hours of Nederland [discussing (and repealing!) “rights of nature.”](https://coloradosun.com/2024/05/07/nederland-rights-of-nature-new-dam-reservoir/#:~:text=Town%20of%20Nederland%20leaders%20loved,to%20build%20its%20own%20dam.) So we’re going by subject, falling far short of John’s comprehensive list, but hitting some high notes from the **2024 legislature**.

**Air pollution:** Advocates for powerful new restrictions on Colorado’s oil and gas industry and any other emitters of ozone-causing gases may look back on the 2024 session and feel pretty good. But maybe not. It’s hard to tell. There were so many moving parts to the clean air debates and backroom negotiations, and so many details added into complex bills, that it may take months to see how effective the new measures will be.
What we do know: In exchange for agreeing to another truce on fall ballot measures from either oil and gas trade groups or their opponents, the Democratic-led chambers passed twin bills increasing enforcement of oil and gas emissions and creating a new mass transit and wildlife-supporting fee from oil and gas production. [Senate Bills 229](https://leg.colorado.gov/sites/default/files/documents/2024A/bills/2024a_229_01.pdf) and[ 230](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/sb24-230) were the packaged deal. More about the transit aspect just below.

To make the deals, though, environmental advocates watched some cherished ideas fall away to another year, or perhaps never. Some wanted a total ban on new drilling permits by 2030; others wanted at least a summer “pause” on drilling activity to cut down on toxic ozone. Many sought a beefed up permitting and punitive fine process in state regulatory agencies.

Nonprofits took heart from different signals of success. **Western Resource Advocates** “celebrated” the new oil and gas fees, without commenting on the overall dealmaking. “The good news is that more funding for existing programs can ensure that Colorado’s distinctive landscapes and diverse wildlife weather the worst effects of climate change,” said **Jon Goldin-Dubois, WRA’s president. “**SB24-230 is an important step – it will partially mitigate oil and gas production’s harms and allow the state to conserve and protect more important natural habitat and wildlife.”

**Transit: **Passenger trains and more frequent bus service were big winners in 2024, in large part because of the air pollution compromises mentioned above. Senate Bill 230, the second half of the big compromise package, raises $175 million a year by the new production fee, and distributes most of it to state and local authorities to build more and better public transit. A smaller share of the new money goes to bolstering open space and wildlife.
In a typical response from environment-minded groups, **Southwest Energy Efficiency Project** executive director and Air Quality Control Commissioner **Elise Jones** said the bill “unleashes unprecedented financial support for expanding bus and rail service to better serve Coloradans across the state. This bill is good news for climate stability, air quality, affordability, and mobility.

**PFAS “forever chemicals”:** The ubiquitous, highly contaminating family of waterproofing chemicals will see a new round of restrictions in Colorado, though sponsors of a bill aimed at closing gaps in previous regulations had to make some concessions on timing and exemptions. More cookware and other common consumer goods on Colorado store shelves will have to be PFAS-free in coming years as[ Senate Bill 81](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/sb24-081) heads to the governor’s desk.
Co-sponsor **Lisa Cutter**, a Democratic senator from Littleton, called it another big step in controlling PFAS toxins. “We got phase-out (of PFAS) in several important categories,” said Cutter, who has been fighting products with unnecessary PFAS additives for years.

**Recycling:** Very much a glass half full/empty proposition this year. State regulators and the biggest recycling nonprofits celebrated the **Joint Budget Committee** pushing forward next steps for the [Producer Responsibility fee](https://coloradosun.com/2024/03/13/colorado-recycling-expansion-costs-critics/). The largest producers of consumer packaging, like **Pepsi**, **Coca-Cola**, **Molson Coors**, etc., will charge themselves a fee that the state will distribute to local governments to expand curbside recycling across Colorado. Smaller businesses continue to attack the complex law, saying it will raise consumer prices and not add much to Colorado’s poor waste diversion rates.
**Pesticides:** Those wanting to rein in excessive pesticide use took a big loss, as a renewed push to allow tighter local regulation of the chemicals failed again when [House Bill 1178](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/hb24-1178) hit business opposition. Towns like Vail wanted to go beyond state regulations in controlling how pesticides are applied, but applicators, restaurants and other businesses apparently argued successfully they could not deal with dozens of local regulations.
**Suncor:** Legislation does not customarily single out businesses by name, but since Suncor is the only major Colorado oil refinery, a bill hiring a new refinery monitor has only one target. Neighbors of the big polluter in north Denver and south Adams County have long wanted the state to either close or strictly regulate Suncor in Commerce City. They’ve demanded permit rejections and far bigger fines, among other sanctions.
[House Bill 1338 ](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/hb24-1338)is what they could get this time around: “a petroleum refinery regulation expert to examine whether a specific petroleum refinery rule should be adopted by the commission and examine other regulatory or nonregulatory measures performed.” There’s also a new rapid response team for complaints of violations, and required state studies for “cumulative impact analyses” for the most pollution-impacted communities.
“It’s clear that one of the biggest winners of our legislative session was our environment,” said Democratic Rep. **Manny Rutinel**, Adams County. “The session was full of difficult negotiations with industry groups, but overall, I was happy with the deals we were able to strike because of the powerful voices of advocates across Colorado who have continued to demand a cleaner and safer environment.”

**Wolverines:** It may be a few years yet, but yes, wolverines that are exceedingly rare in the lower 48 these days will be on their way back to Colorado, a century after they were essentially eradicated from the Rocky Mountains.[ Senate Bill 171](https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/sb24-171) also aims at making wolverine reintroduction far less controversial than the ongoing battles over gray wolves, with the bill supported by state wildlife officials, ski areas, sporting groups and bipartisan legislators. Colorado wildlife researchers will now come up with a reintroduction plan and fashion it to meet federal Endangered Species Act requirements.
“Wolverines are part of Colorado’s natural heritage, and the widespread support wolverine reintroduction has garnered demonstrates how much Coloradoans unite behind wildlife,” said Stefan Ekernas, director of Colorado field conservation at Denver Zoo.

**Waste Tires:** Maybe not the biggest issue, but used-tire mountains have been [an all-time Booth obsession](https://coloradosun.com/2021/01/19/colorado-tire-pile-fire-recycling-solar-oil/). Clearly it’s not just me — Colorado has one of the worst tire mountain problems in the nation. Debates over raising waste tire fees in order to finally rid us of our embarrassing tire monofills recur at the legislature every few years. Colorado’s current waste tire fee of 55 cents, which barely pays for inspecting and administering waste tire rules, was set to sunset at the end of the year.
[Senate Bill 123](https://leg.colorado.gov/sites/default/files/documents/2024A/bills/fn/2024a_sb123_r2.pdf) reauthorizes the whole tire recovery and recycling program, creates a new enterprise fund to spend higher fees, and allows state bureaucrats to raise the fee up to $2.50 per tire to create more grants for reusing them. Each time Colorado reauthorizes and raises the fee, the state reports more success in emptying out those ugly and fire-prone monofills. More about that later in a future edition.
Stick with us in coming weeks as we continue to sort through a flurry of last minute bills and compromise revisions on key environmental issues. And if you notice an important one that was given a thumbs up or quietly killed, that we’ve overlooked, please let us know. The legislators themselves are occasionally surprised at news of what they actually did.

#### MORE CLIMATE NEWS
### CHART OF THE WEEK
A few days ago, I received [a question via social media](https://twitter.com/johningold/status/1785315678473371699) about the **Colorado Family Planning Initiative** and its sustained impacts.

The program, which started in 2009 with the help of grant funding, provided free or low-cost birth control to women, especially intrauterine devices, or IUDs. As my colleague **Jennifer Brown** [has reported previously](https://www.denverpost.com/2017/11/30/colorado-teen-pregnancy-abortion-rates-drop-free-low-cost-iud/), the program led to a dramatic drop in teen pregnancies and abortions from 2009 to 2016, when the grant funding ended.

The chart above shows that teen abortion numbers have continued to remain well below mid-2000s levels. In 2005, Colorado saw 780 abortions in teens ages 17 and younger. By 2016, that number dropped to 256, though it has increased since then.

Looking at the data another way, in 2005, abortions among teens 17 and younger made up nearly 7% of the state’s total abortions. Last year, the proportion was below 3%.

Colorado’s number of teen abortions went up significantly in 2022, when the **U.S. Supreme Court’**s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization opened the door for state abortion bans to take effect and [increased the number of out-of-state patients](https://coloradosun.com/2023/07/27/colorado-abortions-surge-texas-patients/) traveling to Colorado for an abortion. Last year saw more than 4,000 abortions in Colorado for out-of-state residents of all ages, a slight increase over the previous year.

The **Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment** is working to calculate abortion rates for Colorado residents for 2023, in order to see how trends have changed (or haven’t) separate from the out-of-state influx and a growing population. Those figures should be available this summer.

Incidentally, this question came to me via a bit of incomplete information circulating on social media — the idea that Republicans in the Colorado state Senate [killed the family planning program](https://www.vox.com/2015/5/7/8565949/colorado-iuds-republicans) in 2016.

But [the program never went away](https://coloradosun.com/2019/10/21/colorado-abortion-rates-keep-declining-free-iuds-and-easier-access-to-the-pill-are-the-reason/). After the Senate blocked funding, the state [found more private money](https://kffhealthnews.org/news/private-money-saves-colorado-iud-program-as-fight-continues-for-public-funding/) to sustain it for a year. The next year, public funding for the program [received bipartisan support](https://www.durangoherald.com/article/20160407/NEWS01/160409714/0/FRONTPAGE/Teen-IUD-funding-survives-Senate-vote/).

So this is just a reminder to be careful out there with online information. Real-life narratives often aren’t as tidy as they appear on social media.

You can learn more about the family planning program [on its website](https://cdphe.colorado.gov/fpp).

### HEAT MAP
#### CLIMATE
#### HEALTH
Hey, nice to see you down here at the end of the newsletter! You’re that much closer to the end of the legislative session. Hang in there just a little bit longer.

Thanks for reading. Your support of local journalism is one thing we hope never ends.

Til next week.

*— John & Michael*
#### Corrections & Clarifications
Notice something wrong? The Colorado Sun has an ethical responsibility to [fix all factual errors](https://coloradosun.com/corrections/). Request a correction by emailing [corrections@coloradosun.com](mailto:corrections@coloradosun.com).
